sen.j: 安土桃山時代（あづちももやまじだい、1568年 - 1603年）とは、織田信長と豊臣秀吉が天下人として日本の統治権を握っていた（織田政権・豊臣政権）時代を指す、日本の歴史の時代区分の一つ。
sen.e: Azuchi Momoyama Period (1568 - 1603) is one of the age classifications in Japan, and refers to the period when Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI held the right to rule Japan (Oda government/Toyotomi government).

The Azuchi Momoyama period (1568 - 1603) is one of the age classifications in Japan, referring to the period in which Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI held the right to rule Japan (Oda government, Toyotomi government).

The Azuchi Momoyama period (1568 - 1603) is one of the age classifications in Japan, referring to the period in which Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI held the right to rule Japan (Oda government, Toyotomi government).

sen.j: 織豊時代（しょくほうじだい）や安土大坂時代（あづちおおさかじだい）とも言う。
sen.e: This period is also referred to as Shokuho (織豊) Period or Azuchi Osaka Period.
This period is also referred to as the Shokuho (織豊) period or the Azuchi Osaka period.
This period is also referred to as the Shokuho (織豊) period or the Azuchi Osaka period.

sen.j: また、安土桃山時代の元号の大部分が天正だったので、天正時代（てんしょうじだい）と呼ぶこともある。
sen.e: Also, as the name of era used for most of Azuchi Momoyama Period was Tensho (天正), it is sometimes referred to as Tensho Period.
Also, because the name of the era used for most of the Azuchi Momoyama period was Tensho (天正), it is sometimes referred to as the Tensho period.
Also, because the name of the era used for most of the Azuchi Momoyama period was Tensho (天正), it is sometimes referred to as the Tensho period.

sen.j: 織田信長の居城であった安土城、豊臣秀吉の居城であった伏見城（桃山）から、このように呼ばれる。
sen.e: It was given this name, from Azuchi-jo Castle where Nobunaga ODA resided, and from Fushimi-jo Castle where Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI resided.
It was given this name based on Azuchi-jo Castle, where Nobunaga ODA resided, and from Fushimi-jo Castle, where Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI resided.

The name given to this period is based on the name of the castle where Nobunaga ODA resided, Azuchi-jo Castle, and the name of the castle where Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI resided, Momoyama-jo Castle (also known as Fushimi-jo Castle).
sen.cmt: 全体的に訳し直しました。

sen.j: 特に、豊臣家が全国支配を担った後半を桃山時代といい、この時代を中心に栄えた文化を桃山文化と呼ぶ。
sen.e: In particular, the latter half of this period, when Toyotomi clan tried to control the entire country, is referred to as Momoyama Period, and the culture which flourished mainly in this age, is called Momoyama Culture.

Particularly, the latter half of this period, when the Toyotomi clan tried to control the entire country, is referred to as the Momoyama period, and the culture that flourished in this age is called the Momoyama culture.

Particularly, the latter half of this period, when the Toyotomi family tried to control the entire country, is referred to as the Momoyama period, and the culture that flourished in this age is called the Momoyama culture.

sen.j: ただし、桃山の名称は江戸時代になって廃城された伏見城の跡地に桃の木が植えられたことから名付けられたもので、桃山城と呼ばれる城が存在したわけではない。
sen.e: However, the name of Momoyama (has meaning of peach mountain) was taken from the fact that peach trees were grown on the site of Fushimi-jo Castle, which was destroyed in Edo Period, and does that mean that a castle named Momoyma-jo Castle existed.

However, the name of Momoyama (which means peach mountain) was taken from the fact that peach trees were grown on the site of Fushimi-jo Castle, which was destroyed in the Edo Period, which indicates that a castle called Momoyma-jo Castle existed.

However, the name of Momoyama (meaning peach mountain) was taken from the fact that peach trees were grown on the site of Fushimi-jo Castle, which was destroyed in the Edo Period, which indicates that a castle called Momoyama-jo Castle existed.

sen.j: そのため、歴史的経緯を尊重するなら“伏見時代”の方が適切な呼称となるが、そもそも、安土城は完成からわずか3年余りしか存在しておらず、伏見城（木幡山）も完成から2年後に秀吉が死去するなど、それぞれ在城は短期間であり、これらを時代の呼称に用いること自体が適切ではないという主張もある。
sen.e: Therefore, if we are to respect historical background, "Fushimi Period" will be a more appropriate name, but in the first place, Azuchi-jo Castle existed only for slightly more than 3 years since it was completed, and in the case of Fushimi-jo Castle (Mt. Kohata) also, Hideyoshi died after 2 years from its completion, and the time both rulers stayed within the respective castle was short, and thus some assert that use of the name of the castles to symbolize the period itself, is not appropriate.

Therefore, if we are to respect the historical background, the "Fushimi Period" will be a more appropriate name, but in the first place Azuchi-jo Castle existed only for slightly more than three years after its completion, and in the case of Fushimi-jo Castle (Mt. Kohata), Hideyoshi died just two years after its completion; consequently, the time both rulers stayed within the respective castles was short, and thus some assert that the use of the name of the castles to symbolize the period is not appropriate.

Therefore, if we are to respect the historical background, the "Fushimi Period" will be a more appropriate name, but in the first place Azuchi-jo Castle existed only for slightly more than three years after its completion, and in the case of Fushimi-jo Castle (Mt. Kohata), Hideyoshi died just two years after its completion; consequently, the time both rulers stayed within the respective castles was short, and thus some assert that the use of the name of the castles to symbolize the period is not appropriate.

sen.j: そのため、近年は織豊時代という呼び方も広まっており、安土大坂時代、または天正時代の呼称を提案するひともいる。
sen.e: Because of such reasons, the name of Shokuho Period is also spreading in recent years, and some suggest the names of Azuchi Osaka Period or Tensho Period.
Because of such reasons, the name of Shokuho Period is also spreading in recent years, and some suggest the names of Azuchi Osaka Period or Tensho Period.
Because of such reasons, the name of Shokuho Period is also spreading in recent years, and some suggest the names of Azuchi Osaka Period or Tensho Period.

sen.j: 安土桃山時代の始期と終期には複数の見解が存在する。
sen.e: There are several opinions regarding the start and the end of Azuchi Period.
There are several opinions regarding the start and end of the Azuchi Period.
There are several opinions regarding the start and end of the Azuchi Momoyama period.

sen.j: 始期は織田信長が足利義昭を奉じて京都に上洛した永禄11年（1568年）が有力であるが、義昭が京都から放逐された元亀4年（1573年）、安土城の築城が始まった天正4年（1576年）とする考えもある。
sen.e: As for the start, a strong view is that the period started in 1568, when Nobunaga ODA obeyed Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA and arrived in Kyoto, but others assert that it was in 1573, when Yoshiaki was banished from Kyoto, or in 1576, when construction of Azuchi-jo Castle started.

As for the start, a strong view is that the period started in 1568 when Nobunaga ODA obeyed Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA and arrived in Kyoto, but others assert that it was in 1573, when Yoshiaki was banished from Kyoto, or 1576, when the construction of Azuchi-jo Castle started.

As for the start, a strong view is that the period started in 1568 when Nobunaga ODA obeyed Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA and arrived in Kyoto, but others assert that it was in 1573, when Yoshiaki was banished from Kyoto, or 1576, when the construction of Azuchi-jo Castle started.

sen.j: 終期は、豊臣秀吉が死去した慶長3年（1598年）、関ヶ原の戦いで徳川家康が勝利した慶長5年（1600年）、家康が征夷大将軍に任じられ江戸幕府を開いた慶長8年（1603年）などがある。
sen.e: Regarding the end, there are such views as it was in 1598, when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI died, or in 1600 when Ieyasu TOKUGAWA won the Battle of Sekigahara, or in 1603 when Ieyasu established Edo Bakufu, etc..
sen.cmt: いずれも英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: Regarding the end, there are such views as it was in 1598, when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI died, or in 1600 when Ieyasu TOKUGAWA won the Battle of Sekigahara, or in 1603 when Ieyasu established the Edo Bakufu, etc.

Regarding the end, there are such views as it was in 1598, when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI died, or in 1600 when Ieyasu TOKUGAWA won the Battle of Sekigahara, or in 1603 when Ieyasu established the Edo Bakufu, etc.

sen.j: 何れにしても、「織田・豊臣の時代」という概念をどこで区分するかの違いではあるが、室町時代、戦国時代 (日本)と重複してしまうことが、その定義付けを複雑化させている。
sen.e: In any case, it is a matter of where to divide 'the period of Oda/Toyotomi', but the definition of this period has become complicated, because it overlaps with Muromachi Period and with the age of civil war (Japan).

In any case, it is a matter of where to divide 'the period of Oda/Toyotomi,' but the definition of this period has become complicated because it overlaps the Muromachi period and the age of civil war (Japan).

In any case, it is a matter of where to divide 'the period of Oda/Toyotomi,' but the definition of this period has become complicated because it overlaps the Muromachi period and the age of civil war (Japan).

tit.j: 織田信長による政権の確立
tit.e: Establishment of government by Nobunaga ODA
Establishment of government by Nobunaga ODA
Establishment of government by Nobunaga ODA

sen.j: 戦国大名の中で織田信長の勢力が次第に強大になり、足利義昭を奉じて京都に上洛したことで、信長による政権の運営が始まることになった。
sen.e: Among Daimyo's of the age of civil war, Nobunaga ODA's powers gradually became extremely strong, and by obeying Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA and arriving in Kyoto, government by Nobunaga began.
Among the daimyos of the age of civil war, Nobunaga ODA's powers gradually became extremely strong, and by obeying Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA and arriving in Kyoto, government by Nobunaga began.
Among the daimyos of the age of civil war, Nobunaga ODA's powers gradually became extremely strong, and by obeying Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA and arriving in Kyoto, government by Nobunaga began.

sen.j: 元亀4年（1573年）に足利義昭を京から放逐すると、室町幕府は事実上崩壊し、名実共に織田政権が確立する。
sen.e: When he exiled Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA from Kyoto in 1573, Muromachi Bakufu virtually collapsed, and Oda government was established both in name and reality.
When he exiled Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA from Kyoto in 1573, Muromachi Bakufu virtually collapsed, and the Oda government was established in name and reality.
When he exiled Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA from Kyoto in 1573, Muromachi Bakufu virtually collapsed, and the Oda government was established in name and reality.

sen.j: さらに、天正4年（1576年）に安土城の築城が始まり天下布武への流れが現実のものになりつつあることを世に知らしめる。
sen.e: Furthermore, start of construction of Azuchi-jo Castle in 1576, announced to the world that the trend towards Tenka Fubu (天下布武) is gradually becoming an actual fact.
Furthermore, the start of construction of Azuchi-jo Castle in 1576 announced to the world that the trend toward Tenka Fubu (天下布武) was gradually becoming a fact.
Furthermore, the start of construction of Azuchi-jo Castle in 1576 announced to the world that the trend toward Tenka Fubu (天下布武) was gradually becoming a fact.

sen.j: こうした中、信長の支配により平和を取り戻した京を中心に新たな文化が花開いていった。
sen.e: In such environment, new culture was starting to bloom centering in Kyoto, which was regaining peace through control by Nobunaga.
In such an environment, a new culture was starting to bloom; it was centered on Kyoto, which was regaining peace through control by Nobunaga.
In such an environment, a new culture was starting to bloom; it was centered on Kyoto, which was regaining peace through control by Nobunaga.

sen.j: 信長はその後も勢力を拡大し日本中央部を制圧するに至るが、天下統一の目前と思われた天正10年（1582年）に本能寺の変で倒れた。
sen.e: Nobunaga since then further expanded power, and eventually controlled central Japan, but in 1582 when it seemed he was very close to unifying Japan, he was defeated in Honnoji Incident.

Subsequently, Nobunaga further expanded his power and eventually controlled central Japan; however, in 1582, when it seemed he was very close to unifying Japan, he was defeated in the Honnoji Incident.

Subsequently, Nobunaga further expanded his power and eventually controlled central Japan; however, in 1582, when it seemed he was very close to unifying Japan, he was defeated in the Honnoji Incident.

tit.j: 豊臣秀吉による天下統一
tit.e: The Unification of Japan by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI
The Unification of Japan by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI

sen.j: 本能寺の変に対し羽柴秀吉は逸早く京に駆け付け首謀者である明智光秀を破った（山崎の戦い）。
sen.e: Upon occurrence of Honnoji Incident, Hideyotshi TOYOTOMI arrived in Kyoto earlier than anyone else, and defeated the leader, Mitsuhide AKECHI (the Battle of Yamazaki).
Upon the occurrence of the Honnoji Incident, Hideyotshi TOYOTOMI arrived in Kyoto before anyone else and defeated the leader, Mitsuhide AKECHI, in the Battle of Yamazaki.
Upon the occurrence of the Honnoji Incident, Hideyoshi HASHIBA arrived in Kyoto before anyone else and defeated the leader, Mitsuhide AKECHI, in the Battle of Yamazaki.

sen.j: これにより織田政権内での主導権を掌握した秀吉は清洲会議や賤ヶ岳の戦いを経て信長の後継者として地位を固め、天正11年1583年には大坂城の築城を開始する。
sen.e: Hideyoshi consequently grasped leadership within Oda government, and strengthened his position as Nobunaga's successor through Kiyosu Meeting and the Battle of Shizugatake, and in 1583, started construction of Osaka-jo Castle.

Consequently, Hideyoshi seized leadership within the Oda government and strengthened his position as Nobunaga's successor through the Kiyosu Meeting and the Battle of Shizugatake; then, in 1583, he started the construction of Osaka-jo Castle.

Consequently, Hideyoshi seized leadership within the Oda government and strengthened his position as Nobunaga's successor through the Kiyosu Meeting and the Battle of Shizugatake; then, in 1583, he started the construction of Osaka-jo Castle.

sen.j: 天正14年（1586年）には関白・太政大臣に任ぜられ豊臣姓を賜り、天正18年（1590年）に日本を統一し全国で検地と刀狩りを実施させ政権の安定に力を注いだ。
sen.e: Hideyoshi was appointed as chief adviser to the Emperor/grand minister of state in 1586, and was given the surname of Toyotomi from the Emperor, and in 1590, unified Japan and endeavored to stabilize his government by conducting land surveys and sword hunts throughout the country.
sen.cmt: 英辞郎 on the WEB、英辞郎 on the WEB、Webster's Online Dictionary、http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110000255879/
sen.e: Hideyoshi was in 1586 appointed as grand minister of state and chief adviser to the Emperor, and was given the surname Toyotomi by the Emperor; in 1590 he unified Japan and endeavored to stabilize his government by conducting land surveys and sword hunts throughout the country.

Hideyoshi was in 1586 appointed as grand minister of state and chief adviser to the Emperor, and was given the surname Toyotomi by the Emperor; in 1590 he unified Japan and endeavored to stabilize his government by conducting land surveys and sword hunts throughout the country.

sen.j: また、文禄1年（1592年）秀吉は明の征服を目論んで文禄・慶長の役を起こしたが、経由地であるはずの朝鮮で戦況が膠着化してしまう。
sen.e: Also, in 1592 he conducted the Bunroku-Keicho War, seeking to conquer Ming, but war situation reached a deadlock in Korea, which was supposed to be only a way through to Ming.
Also, in 1592 he conducted the Bunroku-Keicho War, seeking to conquer Ming, but the situation reached a deadlock in Korea, which was supposed to be the only route through to Ming.
Also, in 1592 he conducted the Bunroku-Keicho War, seeking to conquer Ming, but the situation reached a deadlock in Korea, which was supposed to be the only route through to Ming.

sen.j: 一方、国内は天下統一による平和がもたらされたことなどから、諸大名は領国の経営に力を注ぎ、各地で都市が興隆していった。
sen.e: On the other hand, peace arrived in Japan as the result of unification, and various Daimyo's put in efforts to manage their countries, and cities in various parts of Japan prospered.
On the other hand, peace came to Japan as the result of unification; various daimyos endeavored to manage their countries, and cities in various parts of Japan prospered.
On the other hand, peace came to Japan as the result of unification; various daimyos endeavored to manage their countries, and cities in various parts of Japan prospered.

sen.j: また、秀吉自身は京を活動の拠点とし茶の湯を始めとする文化活動を自らも積極的に行った。
sen.e: Hideyoshi based his activities in Kyoto and directly and aggressively engaged in cultural activities such as tea ceremony, etc..
Hideyoshi based his activities in Kyoto and directly and aggressively engaged in cultural activities such as tea ceremony, etc.
Hideyoshi based his activities in Kyoto and directly and aggressively engaged in cultural activities such as tea ceremony, etc.

sen.j: こうしたことに加え、南蛮貿易による異文化との接触や朝鮮陶法の伝播などにより、文化は新たな時代を向かえ“桃山文化”と呼ばれることになった。
sen.e: In addition to the above, through contact with different cultures via trade with Southeast Asian countries, spreading of manufacturing techniques of Korean pottery, etc., culture has entered a new era, and came to be referred to as "Momoyama Culture".

In addition to the above, through contact with different cultures via trade with the countries of Southeast Asia, the spread of manufacturing techniques of Korean pottery, etc., culture entered a new era and came to be referred to as the Momoyama culture."

In addition to the above, through contact with different cultures via trade with Spain and Portugal, the spread of manufacturing techniques of Korean pottery, etc., culture entered a new era and came to be referred to as the "Momoyama culture."
sen.cmt: 南蛮貿易：Southeast Asian countries→Spain and Portugal"挿入

tit.e: The end of the Toyotomi period
The end of the Toyotomi period

sen.j: 慶長3年（1598年）秀吉が死去すると、五大老の筆頭である徳川家康が頭角を現し朝鮮遠征軍撤退の和平交渉でも主導権を握り実質的な政権運営者へとのし上がっていった。
sen.e: When Hideyoshi died in 1598, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who was the leader of Council of Five Elders (五大老), started to distinguish himself and took the lead in negotiations for peace in withdrawal of the army which had advanced into Korea, and rose to become the person who virtually controlled the government.

When Hideyoshi died in 1598, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who was the leader of the Council of Five Elders (五大老), started to distinguish himself and took the lead in negotiations for peace through the withdrawal of the army, which had advanced into Korea; subsequently, he became the person who virtually controlled the government.

When Hideyoshi died in 1598, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who was the leader of the Council of Five Elders (五大老), started to distinguish himself and took the lead in negotiations for peace through the withdrawal of the army, which had advanced into Korea; subsequently, he became the person who virtually controlled the government.

sen.j: これに対し石田三成を中心とした反家康勢力が反発し慶長5年（1600年）に全国を二分する関ヶ原の戦いが勃発した。
sen.e: Anti-Ieyasu powers lead by Mitsunari ISHIDA opposed such moves by Ieyasu, resulting in the Battle of Sekigahara, which divided the entire country into 2 parties.
Anti-Ieyasu powers led by Mitsunari ISHIDA opposed such moves by Ieyasu, resulting in the Battle of Sekigahara, which divided the entire country into two parties.
Anti-Ieyasu powers led by Mitsunari ISHIDA opposed such moves by Ieyasu, resulting in the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600, which divided the entire country into two parties.

sen.j: これに勝利した徳川家康は政権の基盤を固め慶長8年（1603年）征夷大将軍に任じられる。
sen.e: Ieyasu, who won this war, strengthened the base of his government, and was appointed by the Emperor as Seii Taishogun in 1603.
Ieyasu, who won the war, strengthened the base of his government and was appointed by the Emperor as Seii Taishogun in 1603.
Ieyasu, who won the war, strengthened the base of his government and was appointed by the Emperor as Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") in 1603.
sen.cmt: "Seii Taishogun"→"Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")"に変更しました。

sen.j: これにより安土桃山時代は完全に終わりを告げ未曾有の太平、江戸時代が始まった。
sen.e: By this Azuchi Momoyama Period completely ended, and an unprecedented age of peace, Edo Period, started.
With this the Azuchi Momoyama period ended completely, and an unprecedented age of peace--the Edo period--was born.
With this the Azuchi Momoyama period ended completely, and an unprecedented age of peace--the Edo period--was born.

sen.j: 織田信長、足利義昭を奉じ、上洛（永禄11年・1568）
sen.e: Nobunaga ODA obeyed Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA and arrived in Kyoto (in 1568)
Nobunaga ODA obeyed Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA and arrived in Kyoto (in 1568).
Nobunaga ODA obeyed Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA and arrived in Kyoto (in 1568).

sen.j: 室町幕府滅亡（元亀4年・1573）
sen.e: Fall of Muromachi Bakufu (in 1573)
The Fall of Muromachi Bakufu (1573)
The Fall of Muromachi Bakufu (1573)

sen.j: 長篠の戦い（天正3年・1575）
sen.e: The Battle of Nagashino (in 1575)
The Battle of Nagashino (1575)
The Battle of Nagashino (1575)

sen.j: 織田信長、安土城を築く（天正4年・1576）
sen.e: Nobunaga ODA constructs Azuchi-jo Castle (in 1576)
Nobunaga ODA constructed Azuchi-jo Castle (1576).
Nobunaga ODA constructed Azuchi-jo Castle (1576).

sen.j: 織田信長、顕如を降伏させ、石山本願寺との対決を終わらせる（石山合戦（1570～1580））
sen.e: Nobunaga makes Kennyo (顕如) surrender, and concludes the war with Ishiyama Hongwanji Temple (石山本願寺)(Ishiyama War (1570 – 1580))
Nobunaga forced Kennyo (顕如) to surrender and concluded the war with Ishiyama Hongwanji Temple (石山本願寺) (Ishiyama War (1570 – 1580)).
Nobunaga ODA forced Kennyo (顕如) to surrender and concluded the war with Ishiyama Honganji Temple (石山本願寺) (Ishiyama War (1570 –1580)).
sen.cmt: ODA挿入Hongwanji→Honganji （用語リストミス？）スペース削除

sen.j: 本能寺の変（天正9年・1582）→山崎の戦：明智光秀の謀反も俗に言う三日天下で終わる。
sen.e: Honnoji Incident(in 1582)=>the Battle of Yamazaki: treason by Mitsuhide AKECHI ended in so-called short-lived rule.
The Honnoji Incident (1582)=>the Battle of Yamazaki: treason by Mitsuhide AKECHI ended in a so-called "short-lived rule."
The Honnoji Incident (1582)=>the Battle of Yamazaki: treason by Mitsuhide AKECHI ended in a relatively short-lived rule.
sen.cmt: 原文に『』のない" "を取りました。

sen.j: 清洲会議（天正9年・1582）→賤ヶ岳の戦い（天正10年・1583）：織田信長の後継争いで、筆頭家老であった柴田勝家と豊臣秀吉が反目。
sen.e: Kiyosu Meeting (in 1582) =>the Battle of Shizugatake (in 1583): in the fight for the position as Nobunaga ODA's successor, Katsuie SHIBATA, who was the top senior retainer, was at enmity with Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

The Kiyosu Meeting (1582) =>the Battle of Shizugatake (1583): in the fight for the position as Nobunaga ODA's successor, Katsuie SHIBATA, who was the top senior retainer, was at enmity with Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

The Kiyosu Meeting (1582)=>the Battle of Shizugatake (1583): in the fight for the position as Nobunaga ODA's successor, Katsuie SHIBATA, who was the top senior retainer, was at enmity with Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 羽柴秀吉が勝ち、敗れた柴田勝家が自害。
sen.e: Hideyoshi won, and Katsuie SHIBATA who was defeated committed suicide.
Hideyoshi won, and the defeated Katsuie SHIBATA committed suicide.
Hideyoshi HASHIBA won, and the defeated Katsuie SHIBATA committed suicide.

sen.j: 羽柴秀吉、石山本願寺跡地に大坂城築城（天正10年・1583）
sen.e: Hideyoshi HASHIBA constructed Osaka-jo Castle on the site of Ishiyama Hongwanji Temple (in 1583)
Hideyoshi HASHIBA constructed Osaka-jo Castle on the site of Ishiyama Hongwanji Temple (1583).

sen.j: 羽柴秀吉、藤原氏を称し関白に就任。

sen.j: （天正13年・1585）、同年四国征伐

sen.j: 羽柴秀吉、太政大臣となり、豊臣姓を賜る（天正14年・1586）
sen.e: Hideyoshi HASHIBA was granted the surname of Toyotomi by the Emperor, and became grand minister of state (in 1586)

sen.j: 九州征伐（天正15年・1587）→九州平定後、博多で伴天連追放令発布

sen.j: 小田原の役、後北条氏が豊臣秀吉に降伏、天下統一（天正18年・1590）
sen.e: After the siege of Odawara, Go-Hojo clan surrendered to Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and Japan was unified (in 1590)

sen.j: 安土桃山時代には、都市部において豪商と呼ばれる新興商人が成長し、その富を背景にした豪華で大掛かりな文化傾向が見られる。
sen.e: In Azuchi Momoyama Period, newly emerging merchants who were called wealthy merchants rose in power, and a tendency towards luxurious and large-scale culture supported by their wealth, is seen.

In the Azuchi Momoyama period, newly emerging merchants who were considered wealthy merchants rose in power, and a tendency toward a luxurious and large-scale culture emerged, supported by their wealth.

In the Azuchi Momoyama period, newly emerging merchants who were considered wealthy merchants rose in power, and a tendency toward a luxurious and large-scale culture emerged, supported by their wealth.

sen.j: また信長の政策により、仏教勢力の力が中央では弱まった。
sen.e: Also, as a result of policies by Nobunaga, powers of Buddhists weakened in the center of the country, and there were fewer works related to Buddhism, and were replaced by works that focuses on human beings, and is prepared in a modern style.

Also, as a result of policies by Nobunaga, the powers of Buddhists weakened at the center of the country; fewer works were produced in relation to Buddhism, being replaced by works that focused on human beings, as prepared in a modern style.
Also, as a result of Nobunaga's policies, the power exercised by the Buddhists weakened at the center of the country.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 仏教主義的な作品が減り、代わりに人間中心、現世的な作風が見受けられる。
sen.e: Fewer works based on Buddhist themes were produced, with newer works focusing more on human beings and prepared in a more modern style.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 茶の湯が流行し、唐物の名物茶道具が珍重された一方で、それへの反抗としてのわび茶も発達した。
sen.e: Tea ceremony became popular, and fine utensils for the tea ceremony imported from Tang were prized, but on the other hand, Wabi-cha (わび茶) also developed, as a resistance to such tendency.
The tea ceremony became popular, and accordingly fine utensils imported from Tang were prized; on the other hand, Wabi-cha (わび茶) also developed as a resistance to such a tendency.
The tea ceremony became popular, and accordingly fine utensils imported from Tang were prized; on the other hand, Wabi-cha (わび茶) also developed as a resistance to such a tendency.

sen.j: 茶器が大名から家臣への報奨とされたり、茶会が武将と豪商を結ぶなど政治にも影響した。
sen.e: Sometimes, utensils for the tea ceremony were given by a Daimyo to his vassal as a prize, or tea ceremony affected political events by acting to strengthen the ties between samurai's and merchants.

Sometimes, utensils for the tea ceremony were given by a daimyo to his vassal as a prize, or the tea ceremony affected political events by serving to strengthen the ties between the samurai and the merchants.

sen.j: 特筆すべき点としては、天文 (元号)18年（1549年）のフランシスコ・ザビエル来日以来の南蛮貿易によってもたらされた南蛮文化の影響が挙げられる。
sen.e: A point to be noted is the impact of Southeast Asian culture brought about through trade with Southeast Asian countries since arrival to Japan of Francisco Xavier in 1549.
One should remember the impact of Southeast Asian culture, which was brought about through trade with Southeast Asian countries since the arrival in Japan of Francisco Xavier in 1549.
One should remember the impact of European culture, which had occurred through trade with Spain and Portugal since the arrival in Japan of Francisco Xavier in 1549.
sen.cmt: 南蛮文化：Southeast Asian culture→European culture南蛮貿易：Southeast Asian countries→Spain and Portugal

sen.j: まだ小規模ではあったが、日本が初めて西洋文化と直接（中国などを介さずに、正式な形で）触れ合ったという点で重要である。
sen.e: t is important in the meaning that Japan had the first contact with western culture (formally, without China, etc., acting as an intermediary), although still small in scale.
It is significant that Japan had the first contact with Western culture (formally, without China, etc., acting as an intermediary), although it was still small in scale.
It is significant that Japan had the first contact with Western culture (formally, without China, etc., acting as an intermediary), although it was still small in scale.

sen.j: 狩野派の絵師が織田信長、豊臣秀吉などその時々の権力者と結び付いた。
sen.e: Kano School painters were directly connected with Nobunaga ODA, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and other powers of the time, and were the central power in artistic circles.

sen.j: 朝鮮陶法：豊臣秀吉の文禄・慶長の役に参加した西日本の大名が、多くの朝鮮人の陶工を自領に連れ帰させ、作らせたのを発祥とする。
sen.e: Manufacturing techniques of Korean pottery: Originated when many Daimyo's from western Japan who attended Bunroku-Keicho War together with Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, brought back Korean potters with them to their own land, and had the potters prepare the pottery.

The manufacturing techniques of Korean pottery originated when many daimyos from western Japan, who had participated in the Bunroku-Keicho War together with Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, brought Korean potters with them to their own land and had the potters prepare the pottery.

The manufacturing techniques of Korean pottery originated when many daimyos from western Japan, who had participated in the Bunroku-Keicho War together with Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, brought Korean potters with them to their own land and had the potters make the pottery.

sen.j: 細川忠興が小倉藩主となった際に、家臣となった朝鮮人陶工に命じて焼かせたものが発祥とする。
